You have bias, (making almost $400 K at this point), but can you set it aside for a moment and read this objectively?

We have known that to increase the temperature by one degree you need to double the concentration of CO2 (Happer etc.). Conversely, to reduce the temperature by one degree you need to halve the concentration of CO2. NASA affirms that temperatures have increased by one degree in the last 100 years. Today's CO2 concentration is 414 ppm. Unless scientists have been wrong for over 100 years, the CO2 concentration must have been half this - 207 - in 1921. Instead, it was only 303 ppm. This opens it to more than CO2 being responsible. I can name a number of events that are happening right now that can account for the temperature rise by themselves (warming phase of Bond Event, Magnetic Excursion and Field Decline, Earth Rotation Speedin up) and point to evidence that temperatures have been at the current level and higher multiple times in the last 10,000 years.

Yes, the climate is changing but even reducing our use to zero will not have the desired result.

Sorry, but I'm going to join in the chorus here and say that this video wasn't up to Physics Girl's usual high standards. I get that global warming is one of the biggest issues we're dealing with, and not enough people are taking the warning of the climate science consensus seriously, but did we really have to call this an "experiment?" If I was still on the fence about climate change, this video would've pushed me a little in the other direction: that perhaps climate change activists aren't being critical if even an educated person with a physics degree from MIT could call this an experiment and had dialogue that implied that the skier had gained some kind of first-hand experience with the climate change reality.

Like almost all videos on divisive topics, this is mostly preaching to the converted. My concern with this one is that it may fan the flames of the climate change denialists more than convince anyone that it's real or that it's a bigger issue than they thought. Climate science is obviously complicated, which affects our about ability to (individually) understand it properly and (even more) our ability to convey the important messages - but I'm not convinced that we should resort to these sorts of tactics. It seems underhand.

Diana, this is embarrassing unscientific alarmist nonsense. Glaciers have receded much faster in the past, e.g. look at the historical data for Glacier Bay Alaska, or Jakobshaben in Greenland, which we also have over 100 years of historical data. Likewise the European Alps. The planet has been much warmer in the recent and distant past. Look at the GISP and Vostok ice core data. The period from 600AD to 1750AD has been the longest cold period in the last 9000 years. What we have seen in the last 300 years is just a natural recovery from this Little Ice Age, and glaciers with their enormous thermal mass take centuries to thaw out and melt. Look at the map of where the Glacier Bay glacier fronts were in the 18th Century, they recession rate was actually much higher rate in the 1800s and early 1900s, long befiore anthro CO2 emissions could have had any impact (which the IPCC admits was not until the 1950s). Yes, the glaciers like Helheim speeded up in the early 2000s, but they have slowed down again since, (but you never hear this). There are multiple factors for variable glacier speeds and recession rates (cloud cover, precipitation, sublimation etc), but natural cycles like the AMO and PDO are key on the global scale, not surfaces temperatures which are way below zero for most of the year at most glacier termina. Very dissapointed to see you falling for and pushing this nonsense climate alarmism agenda. Please do your own research, don't just go with the press releases from Greenpeace and headlines from the Guardian, NYT and the BBC. Sadly some of the scientific journals have also been corrupted - climate science is now a self-sustaining billion dollar industry, in which the institutions and universities only fund research which conforms to the narrative. Meanwhile real environmental problems like habitat destruction and pollution of land, rivers and oceans are being ignored. btw, I have a first in env. sciences, and I went along with the climate~CO2 narrative for 15 years, until I strarted to research climate history (and I read the climategate emails and Andrew Montford's book on the Hockey Stick Illusion, which confirmed everything I had beguns to suspect). If you can't get a copy of the HSI, read this as a taster - http://bishophill.squarespace.com/blog/2008/8/11/caspar-and-the-jesus-paper.html

Nobody seems to account for the 144 Btu per pound ice absorbs as it melts. Melting ice is like ice in a cooler. It helps temper the planet as it melts. When the ice is gone we will know what global warming is. As I understand it, frozen precipitation undergoes up to 5 freeze melt cycles as it falls through the atmosphere. What happens to the latent heat of fusion every time melting occurs in the process. Does some of it radiate to space? Evaporating water takes 970 Btu per pound with it into the atmosphere. What happens to the latent heat of vaporization as the water condenses and falls back to earth? Does some of that heat radiate to space? If so, precipitation is like a built in air conditioning system for the planet. Do you want to take a chance on overloading it?

Some thoughts:

First off, if you want a real solution to carbon emissions right now, go thorium nuclear. Time is of the essence and waits for no one. Otherwise, let's stop with the scare tactics.

Humans have always been worse off under colder conditions. We'll be fine for many thousands of years at current rates of climate change. Our defining feature as a species is that we thrive with environmental change. The idea that we 'thrive' under the current state of nature, so we MUST alter our collective behavior in some specific way makes little sense.

The idea that a "community" will be gone is a poor emotional appeal, especially since new and vibrant communities are constantly replacing the old ones.

Lastly, one could say that we are still in an ice age, one that has been in existence for 3 million years and roughly coincides with our emergence as a genus on this planet. The ebb and flow of glacial and interglacial periods is considered to be a strong factor in our evolution, but this isn't because ice is good for us, but because cold periods often wiped most of us out. In terms of geologic history, this current ice age is just a blip, as are we. Should we fail to survive under the warmer conditions that so much other life thrived within for so many millions of years, maybe we aren't as special as we think we are.

None of the so called forcing mechanisms make sense.
Increased CO² would lead to faster plant growth, which would lower CO².
Intensive agriculture has grown concurrently with industrialization, and would counter any CO² effects.
Higher temperatures would increase evaporation, increasing Earth's albedo and lowering temperatures. Also would lengthen growing seasons and increase food output.
Increased evaporation would increase rainfall and reduce (NOT increase) desertification.
